Despite the available alternatives, password-based authentication still remains a widely used method to secure users important and valuable accounts.
Weak passwords can be cracked easily, making the users account vulnerable to cyberattacks.
An organizational password leak could bring in financial and reputational losses apart from legal consequences.
How to Help Users Regarding Passwords?
Proactive password checking tools: Password strength meters [1, 2].
However, many of these tools rate passwords inconsistently [3].
Advanced Data Driven Password Strength Meter by Ur. Et al has shown compelling results by scoring user passwords using a set of password heuristics [4].
Various training methods in cybersecurity domain have found to be helpful [6, 5, 7].
Some of the previous studies involving serious games include Anti-Phishing Phil [5], CyberCIEGE [8], Phishy [6], GAP [9], Cyberaware [10], PASDJO [3] and Control-Alt-HACK [11] to name a few.
Can a game-based password awareness training teach participants about the various password heuristics?
Can such a training improve the organizational password diversity?
Heuristics: The techniques or practices that have to be satisfied to improve the overall password strength.
From the previous study [4], we selected 16 heuristics based on organizational requirements and assigned them to two game levels.
Password Length Password length must be more than 8 characters H1
Presence of Lower case At least 1 lower case character must be present H2
Presence of Upper case At least 1 upper case character must be present H3
Presence of Digits At least 1 digit must be present H4
Presence of Symbols At least 1 symbol must be present H5
Repeated Characters Not more than 3 consecutive repeated characters (Eg: honeeeey) H6
Duplicated Characters Duplicated characters not more than 50% of total length H7
Repeated Sections Not 3 or more than 3 repeated sections (Eg: abababba) H8
Alphabetic Sequences Not more than 3 consecutive sequences (Eg: 12345, abcde) H9
Symbols Eg: password@ or password@123 have predictable positions H11
Digits Should not be present just at beginning, end or all characters H12
Uppercase characters Should not be present in the beginning or have all uppercase H13
Predictable Structure Should not be present in the list of common structures H14
Keyboard Patterns Eg: QWERTY (English Language keyboards) H10
Date Formats All date formats like DDMMYY, MMDDYY, having month names etc. H15
Black lists Should not be present in organizational blacklist of passwords H16

Passworld: Data Analysis Answers to our Research Questions
Participants created 17,319 passwords, that fell in 11,286 different Password Structures [14].
We tried to answer our research questions based on the analysis of the participant data.
We checked the players correct answer percentages in both pre- and post-tests and analyzed this to find out improvement in users knowledge levels.

Game feedback data was collected from the participants to get insights on how the game fared when it comes to entertainment and educational value.
Strongly Disagree Disagree Neutral Agree Strongly Agree
Participants showed improvements in many complex heuristics like predictable positions of symbols, digits, date formats etc.
Password Structures showed diversity after the game-based training, with over 90% of unique password structures created in Level 2.
H6, H10 and H13 showed decrease in performance, showing that they will need further training.
Gameplay time and heuristic overload will have to reduced in the future versions of the game.
Demographics had at least bare minimum knowledge on cybersecurity topics.
Real-time effects of the game could not be tested, as it involves real-time password monitoring.
Control condition was not followed for the present study.
Long term password memorability not studied.
Passworld is a game created to increase password awareness among enterprise users.
From 4,906 participants data, there is a clear improvement in the number of correct answers given by participants in the post-test compared to pre-test.
Participants have created very diverse set of password structures in Level 2 compared to Level 1.
Participants found the game to be educational and entertaining.
